title: Louis Walsh on facelifts, comebacks and the dangers of fame
text:
In the restaurant of one of his favourite Dublin hotels Louis Walsh is gleefully showing me the physical effects of being Simon Cowell’s longest-serving X Factor judge. I have just told him he is like the Benjamin Button of television, getting younger before our eyes since he first appeared on the show as a fairly unknown Irish pop manager 15 years ago. He starts to chuckle. ‘First Simon made me have my eye bags done. I went to Sharon’s [Osbourne] man for that – and she knows all the best surgeons. Then Simon got on about my hair.’

Louis Walsh reveals why X Factor boss Simon Cowell insisted he had a pop-star makeover

He puts on a camp posh accent: ‘“Darling, you have a bald spot at the back of your head. You can see it on the telly. Not nice. You need to get that sorted.” So I went to a lovely fellow who took some hair off the back of my head and put it on the top. So it’s actually your own hair just put back in the right place. And then there’s the teeth. I’ve had my teeth whitened, but everybody does that now. And that’s it. Simon loves all the grooming. His dressing room is crammed with make-up artists, hairdressers, stylists, people making juices and setting up vitamin drips. I get my suit and have done whatever needs doing. I’m low-maintenance. And I’m not going vegan.’

He is still chuckling, particularly at the dig about Cowell’s recent conversion to veganism, losing two stone in the process. But in fact Walsh rarely stops laughing, exploding with mirth mid-sentence, pausing to tell me unrepeatable, hilarious tales, because Walsh is having a whale of a time back on prime-time TV. On top of that we are indulging him in his favourite subjects: music, gossip and the madness of celebrity. Walsh takes none of it seriously.

He is back on The X Factor after being reinstated by Cowell for the third time after the high-profile and expensive signing of Robbie Williams along with his wife, Ayda Field, and the former One Direction singer, Louis Tomlinson, scored the lowest ratings in the show’s history.

Does he take it personally when he gets the occasional boot from Cowell?

‘No. I’ve had more comebacks than Frank Sinatra,’ he says. ‘The first time I got a bit of a shock but I sort of knew it was coming. You have to keep changing things up. I’ve been in this business all my life. I get it. Everything has a lifespan. Everything needs tweaking to keep it current. But it’s good to be back. I love being back with Simon. There’s something completely addictive about him.’

They refer to each other as ‘Miss Walsh’ and ‘Mrs Cowell’ and have done since they first became acquainted in the music business. After seeing Take That in concert in 1993, Walsh put together five Dublin boys – Boyzone – to rival the British boy band. He tried to get Cowell, who then had his own record label, to sign them, but was told they’d ‘never work’.

Walsh hopes critics are wrong about The X Factor, which is seen by many TV pundits to be on its last legs, with 2018 ratings at an all-time low

Twenty-five million record sales later, Cowell did fly out to meet Walsh’s next band, Westlife, in 1998. ‘He said he’d sign them on the condition I got rid of Shane [Filan] who was the lead vocalist. Shane had the best voice. I told him to cut his hair and dye it blond. Next time Simon saw him he said: “That guy’s much better.” I didn’t tell him for another six months that it was still Shane. We both laughed our heads off. And that’s when we became really good friends.’

We have digressed. It is a professional hazard with Walsh, who is forever taking you down another entertaining rabbit hole. Take, for example, Cheryl. ‘I’ve got to like Cheryl now. It’s taken time. And she’s much happier since she had her baby. We clashed on The X Factor. She had it in for me because I didn’t do much with Girls Aloud and I was meant to manage them. She had a point. But it was because I didn’t want to. None of them could stand each other and I was terrified. And I made things worse because I thought the star was Nadine [Coyle] because she had the best voice. But it was Cheryl and Sarah [Harding] who all the guys fancied so I was totally wrong there.’

He hopes critics are wrong about The X Factor, which is seen by many TV pundits to be on its last legs, with 2018 ratings at an all-time low, the BBC’s Strictly dancing on the grave of their audience figures and ITV’s new Saturday-night entertainment show, The Masked Singer – featuring Jonathan Ross, Davina McCall and Rita Ora – rumoured to be ready to kill off The X Factor for good.

From left: Nadine Coyle, Nicola Roberts, Sarah Harding, Cheryl Tweedy and Kimberley Walsh of Girls Aloud; Louis Walsh was the group’s original manager

This time round The X Factor is a whole new show. Cowell has brought back the original format of three judges – himself, Walsh and former Pussycat Doll Nicole Scherzinger – but changed the format of the show. The first run will involve contestants made up of a heady cocktail of Love Island and TOWIE stars competing for a record deal along with the likes of Vinnie Jones and, bizarrely, BBC journalist Martin Bashir, who famously interviewed Princess Diana in 1995. A second spin-off show – X Factor All Stars – will involve former contestants battling it out to win the crown and reinvigorate their career.

‘He’s turned the whole thing on its head,’ says Walsh. ‘It’s upbeat, it’s entertaining. People will not believe it when they hear someone like Martin Bashir sing.’

So the underlying cruel streak in The X Factor, such as the ‘six-chair challenge’, where contestants were given places in the final only to be swapped at the last minute, all of this has gone?

Walsh nods. ‘That was a mistake,’ he says. ‘Simon admits it himself. A big mistake.’ It is no surprise given the pressure ITV bosses have been under to follow a stringent psychological procedure after two former contestants on Love Island took their lives and The Jeremy Kyle Show was axed earlier this year after three suspected suicides of guests.

Louis Walsh with old friend and fellow X Factor judge Simon Cowell; this series will Walsh’s 14th on the show

Walsh looks serious. ‘You know, I have been so conscious of that right from the beginning. It’s in your head all the time: I hope nothing is going to happen to these people, I hope you can take rejection, I hope you are not going to do something stupid like commit suicide.

‘Rejection is part of the show. It is part of this business, but we do always make sure we are available, that we can talk to people.

‘I’ve lain awake in bed during the shows totally unable to sleep worrying about song choices, worrying about whether they will be on their game. All my contestants have my personal mobile number. We have a very good team behind the scenes. During the run of the show I am up all night worrying about them. It’s always on your mind.’

Cheryl had it in for me because I didn’t do much with Girls Aloud. She had a point. But I’ve got to like her now

To be fair, The X Factor, which has had a psychiatrist on board working with contestants since 2007, has a clean record among its wannabe stars. It is its judges, however, who have presented the more worrying issues. The feud between Dannii Minogue and Sharon Osbourne (both judges on the show 12 years ago) created endless stress for all concerned – ‘I was Team Sharon,’ says Walsh.

Then, after three years judging on the UK show, Cheryl admitted she had a ‘breakdown’ after being sacked from the US show in 2011, and in 2014 Spice Girl Melanie Brown took an overdose just a week before the final show. ‘She called me that night,’ says Walsh. ‘It was the early hours of the morning and she was whispering into the phone and then just rang off. I couldn’t understand what she was saying. I knew her husband was a problem but none of us realised how bad it was. None of us realised she had taken an overdose.’

Walsh is, of course, familiar with the perils of drink and drugs. It makes him sad. ‘The waste of it all. You have a great life. And you let stupid people in around you and then you let it all become a mess.’ He talks about working alongside Britney Spears on that ill-fated US version of The X Factor in 2011. ‘I was sitting next to her on the panel and realised she was wearing ear plugs while people were auditioning. Ear plugs. I couldn’t believe it. We would get through four or five auditions and then we’d notice she’d slumped to the side and we’d all have to have a break. She didn’t engage with me at all until I told her I knew the actor Colin Farrell [whom Walsh rejected when he tried to join Boyzone]. She said: “I love Colin Farrell.” And after that we would talk about Colin Farrell.’ He shrugs. And then smiles. ‘Crazy, isn’t it?’

Walsh himself does not drink, smoke or do drugs. Never has done. ‘I have two addictions. Coffee and [the painkiller] Solpadeine, which I take if I’m feeling run down. That’s it. I’m 67 years old. I worry about dying all the time so I worry about my health. I don’t want to die because I absolutely love my life. I have the worst FOMO [Fear Of Missing Out] so I don’t want to go anywhere. I want to carry on in the music business and in television because it’s basically a hobby and a passion that I actually get paid for. That’s a big part of the reason I’ve never wanted to drink or take drugs because I know I’m so lucky to be in this world.’

Walsh with Britney Spears on the US X Factor in 2012. 'She didn’t engage with me at all until I told her I knew the actor Colin Farrell'

He is reportedly worth around £104 million but lives a fairly modest life. He does, however, own a vast art collection that includes several Warhols, Hockneys and Hirsts. He has homes in Miami, London and Dublin. And he loves to travel, most recently to Los Angeles. A matter of weeks ago he was staying chez Cowell and witnessed a new family side to the man: playtime with his five-year-old son, Eric; early nights and his new healthy vegan regime. ‘I did used to worry about Simon. He never slept. He was all work, work, work but Lauren [Silverman, his partner of six years and mother of his only son] has been the making of him. He loves being a dad.’

Family is important to Walsh. It was his father, Frank, who introduced him to music, the likes of Mario Lanza and the soundtrack to My Fair Lady. The young Walsh, who was bullied at school, found his escape.

Mel B called me in the early hours, but I didn’t realise she’d taken an overdose

‘I was hooked,’ he says, eyes alight. ‘In Ireland they had showbands who would play cover versions and I would follow them. I made friends with the musicians and got some bands on as support and made a bit of money. There was no plan B. I couldn’t sing, I couldn’t play an instrument but I had to be part of that world.’

His first job was with a Dublin agency and his first big find was Johnny Logan, whom he put in for the Eurovision Song Contest and found himself handling a winner and travelling with him to TV stations all over the world. ‘I learned on the job.’

It was his move to manager and mogul that really put him on the map with Boyzone and Westlife, making millions in the process. The secret of his success is, he believes, simple. ‘You have to laugh at everything and don’t get sucked into the madness.’

Interestingly, the thing he liked most about Cowell when they first became friends was that ‘he was so charming to everyone, so hysterically camp and he never, ever cursed’.

He was also impressed at his instinct for a hit. ‘I remember when a guy played Baby One More Time. Simon wanted it. He wouldn’t let up even though the guy was always going to give it to Britney Spears. Simon said to him: “I’ll give you more and buy you a Mercedes.” I like that in him. Relentlessness. It’s what you have to have. JLS were definitely going to win The X Factor when I was their mentor but Simon managed to get Beyoncé to duet with Alexandra Burke and that’s why she won. He’ll do anything to win. He’s a self-made man and he has made more millionaires than anyone in the business.

‘A lot of those millionaires become monsters because they forget they are lucky to be in that position. Like the boys from One Direction. It was Simon who made that band. They weren’t the best singers, they couldn’t write their own songs, they were never The Beatles, but they all made millions thanks to Simon and a lot of them forgot about that.’

I ask if he has any regrets. He shakes his head: ‘I would be very ungrateful if I had. But it would be wonderful if Sharon was on the X Factor with me, Nicole and Simon.’ He giggles as he’s about to take his leave. ‘And she’s got a new face, you know. She’s just had it done. I say: “Sharon, you need to show off your new face.” And she roars with laughter. We both know it’s all a game, so you might as well have some fun.’

‘The X Factor: Celebrity’ begins next Saturday on ITV at 8.35pm
